metadata.source: DBI Information Sheet G-25: Restaurant Building Permit Requirements
metadata.purpose: Comprehensive guide for restaurant building permits — covers DBI, Planning, DPH, and SFFD coordination, step-by-step process, occupancy classification, fees, and common issues

overview.description: Comprehensive guide for restaurant building permits in San Francisco
overview.key_principle: DBI building permit covers BUILDING construction (structural, fire-life-safety, accessibility, energy). DPH health permit covers FOOD SERVICE operations. Both are required — they are separate tracks.
overview.critical_sequence: Planning FIRST → DPH pre-consultation → Design → DBI filing → Parallel review → All agency approvals → Permit issuance → Construction → Inspections

step_1_planning.purpose: Confirm restaurant use is permitted at the address
checks: Conditional Use (CU) permit needed? (many neighborhoods require CU for restaurants)
Any Planning conditions from prior approvals?
Outdoor seating or signage changes need separate Planning review
step_1_planning.note: Planning approval or Letter of Determination required BEFORE building permit application
step_1_planning.section_311: Change of use may trigger 30-day neighborhood notification period

step_2_dph_preapproval.action: Contact DPH Environmental Health for pre-application consultation
step_2_dph_preapproval.purpose: DPH requirements heavily influence construction design — consult BEFORE design
step_2_dph_preapproval.why_first: DPH will identify requirements that affect plumbing layout, ventilation design, equipment spacing, and finish materials. Designing without DPH input leads to costly redesigns.
step_2_dph_preapproval.contact: DPH Environmental Health — Food Safety Program

step_3_design.action: Prepare construction plans incorporating all agency requirements
required_on_plans: Complete floor plan drawn to scale showing entire facility
Equipment layout with numbered schedule cross-referenced to plan
Plumbing plan with grease interceptor location, sizing, and fixture count
Ventilation plan with Type I hood specifications (make, model, CFM, duct sizing)
Finish schedule — floor, cove base, walls, ceiling by room
Electrical and lighting layout with foot-candle calculations
step_3_design.signature_requirement: Restaurant construction typically requires CA-licensed architect or engineer (G-01 Status III) due to commercial kitchen structural/mechanical systems

step_4_dbi_filing.action: File building permit application at DBI Central Permit Bureau
step_4_dbi_filing.routing: DBI routes application to all required reviewing agencies simultaneously
step_4_dbi_filing.fees_collected_at_filing: DBI building permit fees per Table 1A-A based on construction valuation

agencies_reviewing.DBI_building: Structural integrity, fire-life-safety, accessibility (CBC 11B), Title-24 energy
agencies_reviewing.DBI_plumbing: Grease interceptor, plumbing fixtures, water heater, drainage
agencies_reviewing.DBI_electrical: Electrical service, circuits, equipment connections, lighting
agencies_reviewing.Planning: Use confirmation, signage review, exterior changes, CU conditions
agencies_reviewing.DPH: Food safety layout, equipment adequacy, finishes, ventilation, handwashing
agencies_reviewing.SFFD: Hood suppression system, occupancy load, means of egress, sprinkler requirements

step_5_plan_review.timeline: 8-16 weeks typical for restaurant tenant improvement (all agencies combined)

step_6_corrections.expect: Multiple rounds of corrections from different agencies — 2-3 rounds typical
step_6_corrections.tip: Address ALL agency corrections before resubmitting — partial responses delay review

step_7_permit_issuance.prerequisite: ALL reviewing agencies must approve before building permit is issued
step_7_permit_issuance.dph_note: DPH health permit is a SEPARATE track from building permit — health permit issued only after DPH final food facility inspection post-construction
separate_permits_needed: DPH health permit (separate application to DPH)

step_8_construction_inspection.title24_final: M-06 Final Compliance Affidavit must be emailed to dbi.energyinspections@sfgov.org and approved BEFORE DBI final inspection
step_8_construction_inspection.dph_final: DPH conducts separate final food facility inspection — health permit issued upon passing
step_8_construction_inspection.sffd_final: SFFD final inspection for hood suppression, sprinklers, occupancy if >50

restaurant_50_or_fewer.sprinkler_trigger: Per Table 903.2 thresholds (area and story based)

restaurant_over_50.implications: Assembly requirements triggered — more stringent fire, accessibility, and egress requirements
restaurant_over_50.sprinkler_trigger: Fire area >5,000 sqft OR occupant load >100 OR not on level of exit discharge (CA Fire Code 903.2.1)
additional_requirements: Occupant load calculation and posting required
Exit doors must swing in direction of egress
SFFD operational permit for Place of Assembly

bar_lounge.note: Bars and lounges are always Group A-2 regardless of occupant count

occupancy_classification.threshold_note: Occupant load >50 triggers the Group B to Group A-2 reclassification with significant implications for fire protection, accessibility, and SFFD review

occupant_load_calculation.method: CBC Table 1004.5 — occupant load factor by use

restaurant_factors.concentrated_dining: 7 sqft per occupant (standing, bars, counter seating)

occupant_load_calculation.note: Total occupant load = sum of all areas. A 1,500 sqft restaurant with 1,000 sqft dining (unconcentrated) + 500 sqft kitchen = 67 + 3 = 70 occupants → exceeds 50 → Group A-2

abc_licensing.note: Restaurants serving alcohol require a California Department of Alcoholic Beverage Control (ABC) license, which is separate from DBI building and DPH health permits. ABC licensing can take 2-6 months and should be initiated early in the process.
abc_licensing.impact_on_building_permit: ABC license type may affect occupancy classification and SFFD review (e.g., Type 48 bar license = always A-2)

common_code_issues: Accessible route from street entrance to dining area and restrooms (CBC 11B)
Minimum aisle width: 44in general (36in if serving ≤50 occupants)
Exit doors swing in direction of egress travel when serving >50 occupants
Grease duct enclosure — fire rating required per mechanical code
Type I hood fire suppression system — UL 300 listed, automatic
Makeup air system for kitchen exhaust (must be balanced with exhaust CFM)
Floor drains required in food preparation and dishwashing areas
Handwashing stations — one per food preparation area minimum
Grease interceptor sizing per CA Plumbing Code Table 7-3
Slip-resistant flooring in cooking and food preparation areas
Cove base minimum 4in height with 3/8in radius at floor-wall junction

plumbing_permit.covers: Grease interceptor, fixtures, water heater, drainage
plumbing_permit.fee_category: 6PA ($543 — 5 or fewer drainage/gas outlets) or 6PB ($1,525 — 6+ outlets)

electrical_permit.fee_basis: Table 1A-E categories based on outlet count and square footage

mechanical_permit.type: May be included on building permit or separate
mechanical_permit.covers: HVAC, kitchen exhaust hood, makeup air system

dph_health_permit.type: Separate application to DPH Environmental Health
dph_health_permit.fee: Varies by facility type and size — contact DPH

planning_approval.type: Use permit or Letter of Determination
planning_approval.timing: Must be obtained BEFORE building permit application
planning_approval.cu_hearing: May require Conditional Use hearing depending on zoning district

dph_coordination.review_timeline: 4-8 weeks (runs parallel with DBI plan review)
dph_triggers_construction_changes: Equipment layout affects plumbing runs and fixture locations
Hood sizing affects ductwork routing and makeup air design
Finish materials must meet DPH approved materials list
Three-compartment sink dimensions affect space planning
Grease interceptor size affects underground plumbing layout
Handwashing station locations affect plumbing and electrical
Walk-in cooler/freezer placement affects structural and electrical
common_dph_rejections: Missing or incomplete equipment schedule (must be numbered, cross-referenced to plan)
Inadequate handwashing stations (need minimum one per food prep area)
No grease interceptor or undersized grease trap
Finish materials not approved (porous materials in food prep/dishwashing areas)
Insufficient lighting levels at food preparation stations (need 50fc)
Missing floor drains in food prep and dishwashing areas
Inadequate ventilation calculations for hood exhaust
dph_coordination.pro_tip: DPH pre-application consultation can save months by identifying issues before design is finalized

fee_estimates.building_permit: Per Table 1A-A based on construction valuation (plan review + permit issuance)

category_6PA.description: 5 or fewer drainage and gas outlets

category_6PB.description: 6 or more drainage and gas outlets

fee_estimates.electrical_permit: Per Table 1A-E — varies by outlet count and square footage
fee_estimates.sffd_plan_review: Per Table 107-B based on construction valuation
fee_estimates.sffd_field_inspection: Per Table 107-C based on construction valuation
fee_estimates.dph_health_permit: Varies by facility type and size — contact DPH for schedule
fee_estimates.surcharges: CBSC ($4 per $100K valuation) + SMIP (varies by building type)

timeline_expectations.dbi_plan_review: 8-16 weeks typical for restaurant TI (all agencies combined)
timeline_expectations.total_estimate: 4-8 months from planning consultation to permit issuance
timeline_expectations.construction: Varies by scope — add construction + inspection time
tips: DPH pre-consultation can save months by avoiding design rework
File plumbing and electrical permits as soon as building permit is approved
Address ALL agency corrections in each round — partial responses add rounds
